Subjective: Heart palpitations, rapid breathing, and muscle tension for months; worse daily for last 2 weeks. Symptoms occur spontaneously at rest, not on exertion. Palpitations are regular but fast/strong, last ~30 mins, resolve spontaneously. Worsened by coffee. Difficulty falling asleep due to worrying about work; sleeps ~6 hours on work nights, feels tired. No chest pain, dizziness, light-headedness, or irregular heartbeat. No abdominal complaints. Social: Recently graduated doctor. Good support system with friends/housemates. No smoking/alcohol. Request: Rule out physical cause (e.g., anemia); asks about talking to practice nurse.
Objective: Vitals: BP 120/60, HR 65, SpO2 98%, RR 14. General: Calm. Heart: Normal S1/S2, no murmurs. Lungs: Clear to auscultation bilaterally, no added sounds. Abdomen: Exam deferred.
Assessment: Stress-related somatic symptoms, secondary to work-related stress. R/O: Anemia, thyroid dysfunction.
Plan: 1. Blood tests: CBC, Thyroid function, Liver function, Kidney function. 2. Referral to practice mental health nurse for counseling. 3. Advice: Actively schedule relaxation activities, maintain regular sleep schedule, consider contacting occupational health doctor to discuss work adjustments. 4. Follow-up: Check blood results in 2 days via phone or online portal. 5. Safety Net: Return if symptoms worsen or new concerns arise.
